results.title: Chapelcross: Scotland's first nuclear power station
results.brief_description: Shows features of the construction of Chapelcross nuclear power station - the first to be built in Scotland. Presented in a style suitable for non-technical audiences, concentrating on the civil engineering work involved in the construction. Scenes of the official opening ceremony are also included.

results.title: Chaos
results.brief_description: What makes the weather so unpredictable and volatile? Why do epidemics come and go without any discernible pattern and why do social systems, like the Stock Exchange, suffer catastrophic collapses? Could these phenomena ever be predicted? The answer may lie in an exciting mathematical theory - the Chaos Theory - put forward by an intrepid group of mathematicians and physicist. Chaos provides clues to the way in which the universe can seem both ordered and disordered at the same time. This video describes the constituent segments of the Chaos Theory and its practical applications in the real world.

results.title: Channelling baby
results.creator_credit: Oceania Parker Films, New Zealand Film Commission, Caterina De Nave and Christine Parker
results.brief_description: 1971—New Zealand soldiers are heading off to Vietnam amidst hordes of peace protesters and the heady excitement of a solar eclipse. In a column of soldiers stopped to board a military truck, Geoff catches sight of Bunnie, a beautiful hippy whose glorious, intimate smile is the lasting vision he takes with him to war. Destiny brings the pair together a second time, when Geoff returns from Vietnam a few months later. Each has been badly hurt in different ways, but in spite of their personal damage, they fall instantly and passionately in love. They start a life together and Bunnie gives birth to a baby girl. Their lives should be joyously complete, but one day, Geoff and the baby mysteriously disappear, leaving Bunnie devastated. Years later, in the 1990s, Bunnie accepts help from Cassandra, a young woman who claims to be a clairvoyant, to find out what has become of her child. Cassandra brings the couple back together again to solve the mystery of what really happened. Their memories are startlingly different, but pieced together, the truth emerges, bringing escalating consequences. Cast includes Danielle Cormack, Kevin Smith, Amber Sainsbury and Joel Tobeck.

results.title: Channel Seven Sport : Up There Cazaly [advertisement]
results.brief_description:
A television commercial for Channel Seven Sport’s coverage of Australian Rules Football, using the song ‘Up There Cazaly’ written by Mike Brady and Peter Sullivan. The song was inspired by the high flying marks of Roy Cazaly who played during the 1920s. The commercial shows some spectacular high marks and bruising bumps.
Produced by Campaign Palace.

results.title: Channel country
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, John Martin-Jones and W. H. Shepherd
results.brief_description: The West Queensland cattle country. This film shows the plains of South-western Queensland and the intricate network of water courses, which during the wet season flood and provide irrigation for rich natural pastures, on which large herds of cattle are fattened for marketing; but which also brings the mail, freight, news and gossip to the outlying homesteads.

results.title: Changing...perceptions of development and power in the Australian inner city
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Malcolm Otton and Philip Robertson
results.brief_description: Spring Hill, an inner-city area of Brisbane, Queensland, is the city’s oldest residential suburb and is today (1979) under threat. The film looks at two major processes of urban change: the encroachment of commercial development, which results in wide-scale demolition of housing; and the influx of new residents, the affluent middle class, who have a stake in restoring the older housing and retaining the residential character of the neighbourhood. Spring Hill’s traditional residents, those who once worked on the nearby wharves and those drifting in from the bush in search of cheap accommodation, are caught between these two processes. Drawn into the conflict are outsiders: politicians, planners, social workers, even film crews. The film assesses their impact on the community and raises important questions about power, class and social change. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Changing Times - Changing Schools: Establishing Victorian Secondary Colleges
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Ministry of Education, Warren Thomas and Ivan Gaal
results.brief_description: Educational administrators, teachers, parents and students comment on a range of re-organisation arrangements developed to enable Victorian secondary schools to better respond to todays workforce requirements and the needs of young adults in schooling.
